question: Which cranial nerve is responsible for smell?
short_explanation: The olfactory nerve (CN I) transmits smell signals from the nasal mucosa to the brain.
long_explanation: CN I passes through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone and is vulnerable to damage from head trauma, potentially causing anosmia.
applied_example: Loss of smell after a concussion may indicate damage to the olfactory nerve.
text: Which cranial nerve is responsible for smell?

question: Which cranial nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye?
short_explanation: CN VI (Abducens) innervates the lateral rectus, allowing eye abduction.
long_explanation: Damage to CN VI can result in medial strabismus and double vision when looking laterally.
applied_example: Lateral gaze palsy in stroke or trauma may indicate abducens nerve dysfunction.
text: Which cranial nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle of the eye?

question: Which cranial nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the heart and GI tract?
short_explanation: The vagus nerve (CN X) controls parasympathetic functions from the neck to the abdomen.
long_explanation: CN X slows heart rate and stimulates digestion. It innervates organs including the lungs, heart, and intestines.
applied_example: Vagal stimulation can be therapeutic in stress reduction techniques like deep breathing.
source_reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Physiology
text: Which cranial nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the heart and GI tract?

question: Which cranial nerve innervates the muscles of facial expression?
short_explanation: The facial nerve (CN VII) controls all muscles of facial expression.
long_explanation: Facial nerve branches pass through the parotid gland and are vulnerable in Bell’s palsy, where half of the face becomes paralyzed.
applied_example: Massage therapists must be cautious with pressure over the stylomastoid foramen to avoid nerve irritation.
text: Which cranial nerve innervates the muscles of facial expression?

question: Which cranial nerve has three major sensory branches: ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular?
short_explanation: The trigeminal nerve (CN V) is the major sensory nerve of the face.
long_explanation: Its three branches cover facial sensation and the mandibular branch also carries motor fibers to muscles of mastication.
applied_example: Trigeminal neuralgia causes intense facial pain often triggered by light touch.
text: Which cranial nerve has three major sensory branches: ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular?

question: Which cranial nerve controls tongue movement?
short_explanation: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) innervates intrinsic and extrinsic tongue muscles.
long_explanation: CN XII exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal and controls precise tongue movements. Damage causes tongue deviation toward the affected side.
applied_example: Tongue deviation on protrusion is a clinical test for CN XII integrity.
text: Which cranial nerve controls tongue movement?

question: Which cranial nerve carries hearing and balance signals from the inner ear?
short_explanation: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) transmits auditory and equilibrium signals.
long_explanation: The cochlear portion handles hearing, while the vestibular portion handles balance and spatial orientation.
applied_example: Vertigo or sensorineural hearing loss often implicate dysfunction in CN VIII.
text: Which cranial nerve carries hearing and balance signals from the inner ear?

question: Which cranial nerve exits the jugular foramen and innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius?
short_explanation: CN XI innervates muscles responsible for head and shoulder movement.
long_explanation: Spinal accessory nerve is motor-only and can be injured in neck dissection surgeries, causing shoulder droop.
applied_example: Weak trapezius activation in massage clients may indicate accessory nerve dysfunction.
text: Which cranial nerve exits the jugular foramen and innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius?

question: Which cranial nerve controls the superior oblique muscle of the eye?
short_explanation: CN IV (Trochlear) innervates the superior oblique for downward and lateral gaze.
long_explanation: It’s the smallest cranial nerve and the only one to exit dorsally from the brainstem.
applied_example: Trochlear nerve palsy can cause vertical diplopia and head tilt compensation.
text: Which cranial nerve controls the superior oblique muscle of the eye?

question: Which cranial nerve is involved in taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue?
short_explanation: CN VII carries special sensory fibers for taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue.
long_explanation: The chorda tympani branch of CN VII joins the lingual nerve to transmit taste signals to the brainstem.
applied_example: Taste loss in anterior tongue may signal Bell’s palsy or facial nerve injury.
text: Which cranial nerve is involved in taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue?
